fr:mainmatter.html:p: A wild category is given by the following data:

html:ol.html:li: for each A,B:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}, a family of types \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}};

for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}}, an element {\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}} : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,C\right )\mathclose {}}

for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}}, a identification \mathsf {lunit}_{\mathcal {C}} f : {\mathopen {}\left (1_{A};f\right )\mathclose {}} = f and a identification \mathsf {runit}_{\mathcal {C}} f : {\mathopen {}\left (f;1_{B}\right )\mathclose {}}=f;

for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}} and h:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (C,D\right )\mathclose {}}, a identification \mathsf {assoc}_{\mathcal {C}}\,f\,g\,h : f;{\mathopen {}\left (g;h\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}};h.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We describe some basic definitions and results in “wild (incoherent) category theory”, i.e. the study of untruncated category-like objects in univalent foundations that may lack higher coherences and saturation/completeness assumptions. Some of this is based on the Homotopy Type Theory Coq library, as well as ideas from a blog post of Mike Shulman and private conversations with Mike Shulman.
A wild category is given by the following data:

html:ol.html:li: for each A,B:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}, a family of types \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}};

for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}}, an element {\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}} : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,C\right )\mathclose {}}

for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}}, a identification \mathsf {lunit}_{\mathcal {C}} f : {\mathopen {}\left (1_{A};f\right )\mathclose {}} = f and a identification \mathsf {runit}_{\mathcal {C}} f : {\mathopen {}\left (f;1_{B}\right )\mathclose {}}=f;

for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}} and h:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (C,D\right )\mathclose {}}, a identification \mathsf {assoc}_{\mathcal {C}}\,f\,g\,h : f;{\mathopen {}\left (g;h\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}};h.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The definitions here are adapted from Shulman from the setting of intensional type theory to an arbitrary wild category.

Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; a pre-idempotent on an object A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} is defined to be a morphism f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,A\right )\mathclose {}} together with an identification \phi : f;f = f.

Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; a quasi-idempotent on an object A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} is defined to be a pre-idempotent {\mathopen {}\left (f,\phi \right )\mathclose {}} on A together with an identification \chi between f;\phi : f;{\mathopen {}\left (f;f\right )\mathclose {}} = f;f and the following composite identification:
Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be two wild categories. A wild 0-functor from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D} is given by the following data:
In other words, a wild 0-functor is a homomorphism of the underlying graphs.

Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be two wild categories. A wild 1-semi-functor from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D} is given by a wild 0-functor F : \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} equipped with, for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (C,D\right )\mathclose {}} and g : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (C,D\right )\mathclose {}}, an identification \mathsf {seq}_F\,f\,g : \mathbf {hom}_{F}{\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}} = \mathbf {hom}_{F}{f};\mathbf {hom}_{G}{g} .
Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; the identity 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{1_{\mathcal {C}}}}{\mathcal {C}} on \mathcal {C} is defined as follows:
The above may be extended to a wild 1-semi-functor as follows:

Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be wild categories, and let D:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} be an object of \mathcal {D}. We define the constant 0-functor on D:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} out of \mathcal {C} to be the 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta D}}{\mathcal {D}} defined as follows:
The above may be extended to a wild 1-semi-functor as follows:

Let \mathcal {C},\mathcal {D} be two wild categories, and let F,G:\mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be two wild 0-functors from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D}. A wild natural transformation is defined by the following data:

Let \mathcal {C},\mathcal {D} be two wild categories, and let F,G:\mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be two wild 1-semi-functors from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D}. A wild semi-coherent natural transformation is defined by the data of a wild natural transformation \alpha : F \to G together with, for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}}, a higher identification \mathsf {seq}_{\alpha }\,f\,g between \alpha _{f;g} : F{\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}};\alpha _{C} = \alpha _{A};G{\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}} and the composite identification:

fr:title.text: Wild initial objects from universal cones

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Wild initial objects from universal cones

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category, and let I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} be an object of \mathcal {C}. If we may equip a wild natural transformation {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} from the constant 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta I}}{\mathcal {C}} to the identity 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{1_{\mathcal {C}}}}{\mathcal {C}} with an identification c_\alpha : \alpha _I = 1_{I}, then \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} is contractible for all A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}.

(Our proof will follow that of the nLab, which was stated for ordinary categories and functors and natural transformations rather than wild ones. It was Mike Shulman who noticed who noticed that this proof also works for the wild/incoherent notions studied here.)

To show that \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} is contractible, we choose \alpha _{A} : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} as the center of contraction. To identify any f : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} with \alpha _{A}, we use the wild naturality of {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}}. In particular, we have an identification \alpha _f between \alpha _I;f and 1_{I};\alpha _A. By our assumption that \alpha _I=1_{I} and using the wild left-unit identifications \lambda f and \lambda \alpha _A, we may identify f with \alpha _A.

fr:title.text: A wild universal cone from a splitting of the generic element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A wild universal cone from a splitting of the generic element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category, and let I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} be an object of \mathcal {C} such that {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} is a wild natural transformation from the constant 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta I}}{\mathcal {C}} to the identity 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{1_{\mathcal {C}}}}{\mathcal {C}} on \mathcal {C} for some I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}. Now let r:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,J\right )\mathclose {}} and s:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (J,I\right )\mathclose {}} be a section-retraction pair witnessed by \eta : s;r = 1_{I}, and let \sigma : r;s=\alpha _{I} be a splitting of \alpha _{I}:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,I\right )\mathclose {}}. Then we may define a wild natural transformation {\Delta J}\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} and an identification \chi : \beta _{J} = 1_{J}.
(This construction is due to Mike Shulman.)

Define the component \beta _{A}:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (J,A\right )\mathclose {}} to be the composite s;\alpha _{A}; for the wild naturality structure, we fix f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} to define \beta _{f} : \beta _{A};f = 1_{J};\beta _{B} as follows:

Next we identify \beta _{J} with 1_{J}. By incoherent naturality, we have \alpha _{J};s = \alpha _{I}; thus by our splitting of \alpha _{I} we have \alpha _{J};s = r;s and hence by postcomposing r and canceling via \eta :s;r=1_{I} we conclude that \alpha _J = r. Therefore \beta _J=s;\alpha _J=s;r=1_{J}.
The definitions here are adapted from Shulman from the setting of intensional type theory to an arbitrary wild category.

Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; a pre-idempotent on an object A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} is defined to be a morphism f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,A\right )\mathclose {}} together with an identification \phi : f;f = f.

Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; a quasi-idempotent on an object A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} is defined to be a pre-idempotent {\mathopen {}\left (f,\phi \right )\mathclose {}} on A together with an identification \chi between f;\phi : f;{\mathopen {}\left (f;f\right )\mathclose {}} = f;f and the following composite identification:

Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; a quasi-idempotent on an object A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} is defined to be a pre-idempotent {\mathopen {}\left (f,\phi \right )\mathclose {}} on A together with an identification \chi between f;\phi : f;{\mathopen {}\left (f;f\right )\mathclose {}} = f;f and the following composite identification:

Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; a pre-idempotent on an object A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} is defined to be a morphism f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,A\right )\mathclose {}} together with an identification \phi : f;f = f.

Let \mathcal {C},\mathcal {D} be two wild categories, and let F,G:\mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be two wild 1-semi-functors from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D}. A wild semi-coherent natural transformation is defined by the data of a wild natural transformation \alpha : F \to G together with, for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}}, a higher identification \mathsf {seq}_{\alpha }\,f\,g between \alpha _{f;g} : F{\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}};\alpha _{C} = \alpha _{A};G{\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}} and the composite identification:

Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be two wild categories. A wild 1-semi-functor from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D} is given by a wild 0-functor F : \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} equipped with, for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (C,D\right )\mathclose {}} and g : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (C,D\right )\mathclose {}}, an identification \mathsf {seq}_F\,f\,g : \mathbf {hom}_{F}{\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}} = \mathbf {hom}_{F}{f};\mathbf {hom}_{G}{g} .

fr:title.text: A wild universal cone from a splitting of the generic element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A wild universal cone from a splitting of the generic element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category, and let I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} be an object of \mathcal {C} such that {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} is a wild natural transformation from the constant 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta I}}{\mathcal {C}} to the identity 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{1_{\mathcal {C}}}}{\mathcal {C}} on \mathcal {C} for some I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}. Now let r:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,J\right )\mathclose {}} and s:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (J,I\right )\mathclose {}} be a section-retraction pair witnessed by \eta : s;r = 1_{I}, and let \sigma : r;s=\alpha _{I} be a splitting of \alpha _{I}:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,I\right )\mathclose {}}. Then we may define a wild natural transformation {\Delta J}\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} and an identification \chi : \beta _{J} = 1_{J}.
(This construction is due to Mike Shulman.)

Define the component \beta _{A}:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (J,A\right )\mathclose {}} to be the composite s;\alpha _{A}; for the wild naturality structure, we fix f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} to define \beta _{f} : \beta _{A};f = 1_{J};\beta _{B} as follows:

Next we identify \beta _{J} with 1_{J}. By incoherent naturality, we have \alpha _{J};s = \alpha _{I}; thus by our splitting of \alpha _{I} we have \alpha _{J};s = r;s and hence by postcomposing r and canceling via \eta :s;r=1_{I} we conclude that \alpha _J = r. Therefore \beta _J=s;\alpha _J=s;r=1_{J}.

Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be wild categories, and let D:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} be an object of \mathcal {D}. We define the constant 0-functor on D:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} out of \mathcal {C} to be the 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta D}}{\mathcal {D}} defined as follows:
The above may be extended to a wild 1-semi-functor as follows:

The above may be extended to a wild 1-semi-functor as follows:

fr:title.text: Wild initial objects from universal cones

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Wild initial objects from universal cones

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category, and let I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} be an object of \mathcal {C}. If we may equip a wild natural transformation {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} from the constant 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta I}}{\mathcal {C}} to the identity 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{1_{\mathcal {C}}}}{\mathcal {C}} with an identification c_\alpha : \alpha _I = 1_{I}, then \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} is contractible for all A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}.

(Our proof will follow that of the nLab, which was stated for ordinary categories and functors and natural transformations rather than wild ones. It was Mike Shulman who noticed who noticed that this proof also works for the wild/incoherent notions studied here.)

To show that \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} is contractible, we choose \alpha _{A} : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} as the center of contraction. To identify any f : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} with \alpha _{A}, we use the wild naturality of {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}}. In particular, we have an identification \alpha _f between \alpha _I;f and 1_{I};\alpha _A. By our assumption that \alpha _I=1_{I} and using the wild left-unit identifications \lambda f and \lambda \alpha _A, we may identify f with \alpha _A.
